description: TO ELECT A SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE VOTES FOR J.G. CANNON ARE CODED 2. VOTES FOR J.S. WILLIAMS ARE CODED 1.
Issue1: Election of the Speaker of the House

description: TO PASS A HOUSE RESOLUTION PROVIDING THAT THE RULES OF THE 57TH CONGRESS BE ADOPTED AS THE RULES OF THE 58TH CONGRESS, AND THAT THE SELECT COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRIAL ACTS AND EXPOSITION BE CONSTITUTED A STANDING COMMITTEE CONSISTING OF 15 MEMBERS, AND HAVE THE SAME JURISDICTION AS THE SELECT COMMITTEE IN THE 57TH CONGRESS.  (P. 149-1)

TO ORDER THE PREVIOUS QUESTION, ON H.RES. 17, THE ORDER FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 1921, RELATING TO CARRYING INTO EFFECT A CONVENTION BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES AND THE REPUBLIC OF CUBA, SIGNED DECEMBER 11, 1902. (P. 254-1, 258-1)

TO PASS H.RES. 17, THE ORDER FOR CONSIDERATION OF THE BILL, H.R. 1921, RELATING TO CARRYING INTO EFFECT A CONVENTION BETWEEN THE UNITED STATE AND THE REPUBLIC OF CUBA, SIGNED DECEMBER 11, 1902.  (P. 254-1)

TO TABLE THE APPEAL OF MR. WILLIAMS FROM THE DECISION OF THE CHAIR, MADE DURING THE CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 1921, A BILL TO CARRY INTO EFFECT A CONVENTION BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES AND THE REPUBLIC OF CUBA, SIGNED DECEMBER 11, 1902, CHAIR RULING THAT ALL INCIDENTAL QUESTIONS OF ORDER, ARISING AFTER A MOTION IS MADE TO THE PREVIOUS QUESTION AND PENDING SUCH MOTION, SHALL BE DECIDED WITHOUT DEBATE.  (P. 388-2)
TO ORDER THE PREVIOUS QUESTION, ON THE MOTION THAT WHEN THE HOUSE ADJOURN  TODAY IT MEET ON NEXT FRIDAY.  (P. 467-1)

TO ORDER THE PREVIOUS QUESTION ON H. RES. 41, PROVIDING THAT THE COMMITTEE ON POST OFFICE AND POST ROADS BE AUTHORIZED TO REQUEST THE POSTMASTER GENERAL TO SEND TO THE COMMITTEE ALL PAPERS IN CONNECTION WITH THE RECENT INVESTIGATION OF HIS DEPARTMENT.  (P. 51-2 53-1)

TO RECOMMIT H. RES. 41, A RESOLUTION AUTHORIZING THE COMMITTEE ON POST OFFICES AND POST ROADS TO REQUEST PAPERS RELATIVE TO AN INVESTIGATION OF HIS DEPARTMENT FROM THE POSTMASTER-GENERAL WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO AMEND SO THAT THE POSTMASTER-GENERAL IS DIRECTLY REQUESTED, IN LIEU OF THE PHRASING AUTHORIZING THE COMMITTEE TO REQUEST SAID PAPERS.  (P. 54-2)

TO ORDER THE PREVIOUS QUESTION ON H.RES. 76, PROVIDING THAT THE COMMITTEE ON EXPENDITURES IN THE POST OFFICE DEPARTMENT IS HEREBY AUTHORIZED TO REQUEST THE POSTMASTER-GENERAL TO SEND TO THE COMMITTEE ALL PAPERS CONNECTED WITH THE RECENT INVESTIGATION OF HIS DEPARTMENT. (P. 380-2 385-2) (NOTE.-JOURNAL SHOWS SPEAKER VOTING IN AFFIRMATIVE TO MAKE A TIE.

TO PASS H. RES. 76, PROVIDING THAT THE COMMITTEE ON EXPENDITURES IN THE POST OFFICE DEPARTMENT IS HEREBY AUTHORIZED TO REQUEST THE POSTMASTER-GENERAL TO SEND THEM ALL PAPERS RELATING TO THE RECENT INVESTIGATION OF HIS DEPARTMENT.  (P. 380-2 385-2)

TO ORDER THE PREVIOUS QUESTION ON H. RES. 118, PROVIDING THAT COMMITTEE BE APPOINTED TO INVESTIGATE CHARGES OF IREGULARITIES AND FRAUDS IN THE REPORT OF 4TH ASSISTANT POSTMASTER-GENERAL.  NO QUORUM VOTING. (P. 444-2 445-1 448-2)
TO ORDER THE PREVIOUS QUESTION ON H. RES. 118. (P. 444-2 445-1 448-2)
TO RECOMMIT H. RES. 118 TO THE COMMITTEE ON POST OFFICES AND POST ROADS.  (P. 476-1, 444-2, 445-1)

TO AMEND H.R. 9480 (33 STAT 85, 3/18/1904), A BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE LEGISLATIVE, EXECUTIVE AND JUDICIAL EXPENSES OF THE GOVERNMENT FOR FISCAL 1905, BY PROVIDING TO ELIMINATE FROM THE CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION AN APPROPRIATION FOR SALARIES OF EMPLOYEES, AND AN APPROPRIATION FOR NECESSARY TRAVELING EXPENSES, INCLUDING THOSE OF EXAMINERS ACTING UNDER THE DIRECTION OF THE COMMISSION, AND FOR EXPENSES OF EXAMINATION AND INVESTIGATION HELD ELSEWHERE THAN AT WASHINGTON.  (P. 782-2)

TO AMEND H.R. 6295, A BILL FOR PREVENTING THE ADULTERATION, MISBRANDING AND IMITATION OF FOODS, BEVERAGES, CANDIES, DRUGS DRUGS AND CONDIMINTS IN THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, AND THE TERRITORIES, AND FOR REGULATING INTERSTATE TRAFFIC, BY PROVIDING THAT ANY ARTICLE OF FOOD OR DRUGS ADULTERATED OR MISBRANDED WITHIN THE MEANING OF THIS ACT, IS PROHIBITED, AND ANY PERSON INTRODUCING SUCH AN ARTICLE SHALL BE PROSECUTED OR FINED FOR FIRST OFFENSE $200, AND $300 FOR THE SECOND OFFENSE, OR ONE YEAR IMPRISONMENT, OR BOTH. (P. 938-2)

TO ORDER THE PREVIOUS QUESTION ON A SUBSTITUTE FOR H. RES. 150, A RESOLUTION REQUESTING THE SECRETARY OF STATE TO FURNISH THE HOUSE WITH A STATEMENT SHOWING THE NUMBER OF HORSES, CARRIAGES AND AUTOMOBILES MAINTAINED AT GOVERNMENT EXPENSE FOR THE USE OF HIS DEPARTMENT, WHICH SUBSTITUTE RESOLUTION PROVIDES THAT SAID STATEMENT SHALL ALSO INCLUDE THE COST OF HORSES, CARRIAGES AND AUTOMOBILES.  (P. 1138-2)

TO AMEND H. RES. 195, RESOLVING THAT HON. GEORGE HOWELL WAS NOT ELECTED, AND HON. WILLIAM CONNELL WAS ELECTED AS REPRESENTATIVE IN THE 58TH CONGRESS FROM THE 10TH DISTRICT OF THE STATE OF PENNSYLVANIA, BY PROVIDING TO ELIMINATE THE NAME OF MR. WILLIAM CONNELL AS BEING DULY ELECTED AND SUBSTITUTE THEREFOR THE NAME OF MR. HOWELL. (P. 1865-1, 1783-2)
TO PASS THE FIRST SECTION OF H. RES. 195.  (P. 1234-1)
TO PASS THE 2ND SECTION OF THE H. RES. 195.  (P. 1234-1)

TO AMEND H.R. 10954 (33 STAT-15, FEB. 18, 1904), A BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS TO SUPPLY URGENT DEFICIENCIES IN THE APPROPRIATIONS FOR FISCAL 1904, BY AGREEING TO THE SENATE AMENDMENT APPROPRIATING $4,600,000 TO AID IN THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE LOUISIANA PURCHASE EXPOSITION, BUT TO ELIMINATE THE 0TIPULATION REQUIRING THE LOUISIANA PURCHASE EXPOSITION COMPANY TO PAY TO THE GOVERMENT 40% OF THEIR GROSS RECEIPT MONTHLY AND ARRANGE TO LIQUIDATE THIS LOAN AT THE CLOSING OF THE EXPOSITION.  (P. 1739-1,2 1738-2) NOTE: SEE PAGES 1738, 1739 OF RECORD FOR COMPLETE DETAIL.
TO ADJOURN ON WASHINGTON'S BIRTHDAY.  (P. 2208-2)
TO RECOMMIT TO THE COMMITTEE ON NAVAL AFFAIRS, HR. 12220, (33 STAT-324, APRIL 27, 1904), A BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE NAVAL SERVICE FOR FISCAL 1905.  (P. 2449-1)

TO TABLE THE APPEAL OF MR. GRIGGS FROM THE DECISION OF THE CHAIR, MADE DURING CONSIDERATION OF H. RES. 118, PROVIDING FOR A COMMITTEE OF THE HOUSE TO INVESTIGATE CHARGES IN RELATION TO THE CONDUCT OF THE POST OFFICE, CHAIR  HOLDING THAT THE LINKING TOGETHER OF PRIVILEGED AND NON-PRIVILEGED MATTERS IS PROHIBITED.  (P. 3146)

TO RECOMMIT H. RES. 118, PROVIDING FOR A COMMITTEE OF THE HOUSE TO INVESTIGATE CHARGES IN RELATION TO THE CONDUCT OF THE POST-OFFICE DEPARTMENT, WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO RECOMMIT THE PENDING REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE ON POST OFFICES AND POST ROADS TO A SELECT COMMITTEE, SAID COMMITTEE BEING DIRECTED TO CONSIDER THE REPORT, PAPERS, AND COMMUNICATION, SO FAR AS THEY RELATE TO THE MEMBERS AND TO HEAR ANY OFFICIAL OF THE POST OFFICE DEPARTMENT REGARDING MATTERS PERTAINING TO MEMBERS OF THE HOUSE. (P. 3146-1 3151-1 3150-2)

TO ORDER THE PREVIOUS QUESTION ON H. RES. 260, PROVIDING TO EXPUNGE FROM THE CONGRESSIONAL RECORD CERTAIN REMARKS OF HON. ROBERT BAKER OF NEW YORK, AS THESE REMARKS WERE CHARGES AGAINST A MEMBER OF THE HOUSE AND WERE NOT IN ORDER.

TO RECOMMIT TO THE COMMITTEE ON POST OFFICES AND POST ROADS, H.R. (33 STAT-429, APRIL 28, 1904), A BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE POST OFFICE DEPARTMENT FOR FISCAL 1905, WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO ELIMINATE APPROPRIATION FOR NECESSARY AND SPECIAL FACILITIES ON TRUCK LINES FROM WASHINGTON TO ATLANTA AND NEW ORLEANS, AND ALSO FOR NECESSARY AND SPECIAL FACILITIES ON TRUCK LINES FROM KANSAS CITY, MO., TO NEWTON, KAN.  (P.3730-1)

TO RECOMMIT TO THE COMMITTEE ON APPROPRIATIONS, H.R. 14416, (33 STAT-452, APRIL 28, 1904), A BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR SUNDRY CIVIL EXPENSES  OF THE GOVERNMENT FOR FISCAL 1905, WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO ELIMINATE AN APPROPRIATION FOR RENTAL OF OLD CUSTOM-HOUSE TO SERVE AS TEMPORARY QUARTERS FOR THE ACCOMODATIONS OF CERTAIN GOVERNMENT OFFICIAL AT NEW YORK CITY, NO QUORUM VOTING.  (P. 4075-2)

TO RECOMMIT TO THE COMMITTEE ON APPROPRIATIONS, H.R. 14416 (33 STAT 452, 4/28/1904), A BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR SUNDRY CIVIL EXPENSES OF THE GOVERNMENT FOR THE FISCAL YEAR ENDING JUNE 30, 1905, WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO ELIMINATE AN APPROPRIATION FOR RENT OF OLD CUSTOM-HOUSE TO SERVE AS TEMPORARY QUARTERS FOR THE ACCOMODATIONS OF CERTAIN GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS AT NEW YORK CITY.  (P. 4075)

TO RECEDE AND CONCUR IN THE SENATE AMENDMENT NO. 16 TO H.R. 10670 (33 STAT-259, APP. APRIL 23, 1904, A BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE ARMY FOR FISCAL 1905, WHICH SENATE AMENDMENT INCREASES THE SIGNAL CORPS OF THE ARMY, WITH AN AMENDMENT TO THAT AMENDMENT INCREASING THE APPROPRIATION THEREIN.  (P. 4112-2)

TO SUSPEND RULES AND AGREE TO AMENDMENT AS A SUBSTITUTE FOR S. 276 (33 STAT 175, APRIL 23, 1904), PROVIDING FOR THE CELEBRATION OF THE ONE HUNDREDTH ANNIVERSARY OF THE EXPLORATION OF THE OREGON COUNTRY BY LEWIS AND CLARK; THE SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT ELIMINATING ALL AFTER THE ENACTING CLAUSE, AND IN LIEU THEREOF, SPECIFYING GOVERNMENTAL PRACTICIPATION IN THE EXPOSITION, BY THE ERECTION OF AN EXHIBIT AND APPROPRIATING FUNDS FOR THAT PURPOSE.

TO SUSPEND RULES AND PASS A RESOLUTION RELATING TO S. 276, REGARDING THE ANNIVERSARY OF LEWIS AND CLARK EXPEDITION, WHICH RESOLUTION PROVIDES THAT FOR THE REMAINDER OF THIS SESSION S. 276 SHALL HAVE THE PRIVILEGES PERTAINING TO BILLS REPORTED BY COMMITTEES HAVING LEAVE TO REPORT AT ANY TIME.

TO RECEDE AND AND CONCUR IN SENATE AMENDMENT NUMBER 49, TO H.R. 10670, (33 STAT-259, APRIL 23, 1904), A BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE ARMY FOR FISCAL 1905, WHICH AMENDMENT APPROPRIATES $250,000 FOR CONTINUING THE CONSTRUCTION OF A MILITARY WAGON ROAD.  (P. 4434-2)
TO PASS H. RES. 309, ORDER FOR CONSIDERATION OF S. 2259, REGULATING SHIPPING BETWEEN PORTS OF THE UNITED STATES AND PORTS OR PLACES IN THE PHILIPPINE ARCHIPELAGO.  (P. 4440-1)

TO AMEND S. 2259, A BILL REGULATING SHIPPING, IN TRADE BETWEEN PORTS OF THE UNITED STATES AND PORTS OR PLACES IN THE PHILIPPINE ARCHIPELAGO, BY PROVIDING TO EXTEND THE TIME FROM JULY 1, 1906 TO JULY 1, 1909, FOR THE ADJUSTMENT OF THE SHIPPING TRAFFIC BY THE ESTABLISHMENT OF NEW LINES AND PROGRESSING IN THE PREPARATION FOR A COMPLETE CONTROL OF THAT BUSINESS.  (P. 4499-2 4500-1)

TO TABLE H. RES. 278, INQUIRING IF SERVICE VETERANS OF THE UNITED STATES WHO SERVED DURING THE WAR OF THE REBELLION, AND WHO HAVE REACHED THE AGE OF 62 YEARS, SHALL BE ENTITLED TO A PENSION.  (P. 457-2 4589-2)

TO ORDER THE PREVIOUS QUESTION ON H. RES. 319, ORDER FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 14623, AMENDING AN ACT TO PROVIDE TEMPORARILY FOR CIVIL GOVERNMENT AFFAIRS IN THE PHILIPPINE ISLANDS, TO PROVIDE FOR REVENUE, A COINAGE SYSTEM, AND FOR MORE EFFICIENT ADMINISTRATION OF THE CIVIL GOVERNMENT.

TO PASS H. RES. 319, ORDER FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 14623, AMENDING AN ACT APPROVED JULY 1, 1902, ARRANGING TO PROVIDE TEMPORARILY FOR THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE CIVIL GOVERNMENT OF THE PHILIPPINE ISLANDS.

TO PASS H.R. 14623, A BILL AMENDING AN ACT TO PROVIDE TEMPORARILY FOR CIVIL GOVERNMENT AFFAIRS IN THE PHILIPPINE ISLANDS, TO PROVIDE FOR REVENUE, A COINAGE SYSTEM, AND FOR MORE EFFICIENT ADMINISTRATION OF THE CIVIL GOVERNMENT.

TO AMEND H.R. 4483, (33 STAT-314, APRIL 27, 1904), A BILL DECLARING THE TUNNELS UNDER THE CHICAGO RIVER AN OBSTRUCTION TO NAVIGATION, BY SPECIFYING THAT THIS LAW SHALL TAKE EFFECT ON JULY 1, 1906, THIS BEING THE EXPIRATION DATE OF THE CONTRACT BETWEEN THE UNION TRACTION COMPANY AND THE CITY OF CHICAGO. TO PASS H.R. 14749, A BILL ENABLING THE PEOPLE OF OKLAHOMA, INDIAN TERRITORY, NEW MEXICO, AND ARIZONA TO FORM A CONSTITUTION AND STATE GOVERNMENT AND BE ADMITTED INTO THE UNION.  (P. 5152-2)

TO RECEDE AND CONCUR IN THE SENATE AMENDMENT NUMBER 18 TO H.R. 12220, (33 STAT-324, APRIL 27, 1904), A BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE NAVAL SERVICE FOR FISCAL 1905, WHICH SENATE AMENDMENT RELATES TO A NAVAL TRAINING STATION AT GREAT LAKES, AND AMEND THIS AMENDMENT BY PROVIDING THAT THE SITE FOR SAID NAVAL TRAINING STATION SHALL BE SELECTED BY THE SECRETARY OF THE NAVY, BUT HE SHALL NOT PAY A SUM TO EXCEED $250 PER ACRE.  (P. 5188-1)

TO PASS H. RES. 282, PROVIDING THAT AT ANY TIME DURING THE REMAINDER OF THIS SESSION, THE BILL H.R. 7056, CREATING A COMMISSION TO CONSIDER AND RECOMMEND LEGISLATION FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE AMERICAN MERCHANT MARINE, MAY BE CONSIDERED IN THE HOUSE AS IN THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE. (P. 5255-1)

TO AMEND H.R. 17473, (33 STAT-827, MAR. 2, 1905), A BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE ARMY FOR FISCAL 1906, BY PROVIDING THAT HEREAFTER NO RETIRED OFFICERS OF THE ARMY ABOVE THE GRADE OF MAJOR, SHALL, WHEN ASSIGNED TO ACTIVE DUTY, RECEIVE FROM THE UNITED STATE ANY PAY OR ALLOWANCES ADDITIONAL TO HIS PAY AS A RETIRED OFFICER, SO AS TO MAKE HIS TOTAL PAY AND ALLOWANCES EXCEED THE PAY AND ALLOWANCES OF MAJOR ON THE ACTIVE LIST. RES. 503, PROVIDING THAT THE SENATE AMENDMENT NO. 208 TO THE AGRICULTURAL APPROPRIATION BILL, H.R. 18329, WHICH AMENDMENT PROVIDES THAT PARAGRAPH 234, THE REVENUE ACT OF JULY 24, 1897, PROVIDING FOR A DUTY ON INPORTED WHEAT AND A DRAWBACK, SHALL NOT BE HELD EFFECTIVE BY THE PROVISIONS OF SECTION 30 OF H.R. 18329, INFRINGES THE CONSTITUTIONAL PRIVILEGES OF THE HOUSE AND THAT SAID AMENDMENT BE RETURNED TO THE SENATE WITH THIS RESOLUTION. L. 681), A BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE FOR YEAR ENDING JUNE 30, 1906, BY STRIKING OUT, ON PAGE 40, LINE 16, AFTER THE WORD "COUNTRIES", THE CLAUSE ENABLING THE SECRETARY OF AGRICULTURE TO ESTABLISH STANDARDS OF PURITY FOR FOOD PRODUCTS AND DETERMINE WHAT ARE REGARDED AS ADULTERATIONS THEREIN, FOR THE GUIDANCE OF THE OFFICIALS OF THE VARIOUS STATES AND THE COURTS OF JUSTICE. TO DECIDE THE ADMISSIBILITY OF EVIDENCE IN THE IMPEACHMENT TRIAL OF CHARLES SWAYNE, JUDGE OF THE U.S. DISTRICT COURT IN AND FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA, HELD BEFORE THE SENATE SITTING AS A COURT; WHICH EVIDENCE CONSTITUTES THE COPY OF A STATEMENT MADE BY SWAYNE BEFORE THE HOUSE COMMITTEE ON THE JUDICIARY ON NOVEMBER 28, 1904, REGARDING HIS RESIDENCE IN HIS JUDICIAL DISTRICT IN FLORIDA, AND WHICH WAS OFFERED IN EVIDENCE BY MR. PALMER, ONE OF THE HOUSE MANAGERS.
TO AMEND THE ARBITRATION TREATY WITH FRANCE, BY ELIMINATING THE WORDS "AGREEMENT" AS REFERRED TO IN DOCUMENT AND INSERTING THE WORD "TREATY", THEREBY MAKING THE DOCUMENT A TREATY.  (P. 204-1)

TO AMEND AN AMENDMENT TO H.R. 18329, (APP. 3-3-05, 33 STAT. L. 861), A BILL APPROPRIATING FOR THE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE YEAR ENDING JUNE 30, 1906, BY ADDING A CLAUSE PROHIBITING REBATES ON IMPORTS WHICH, WHEN BLENDED WITH DOMESTIC PRODUCTS, ARE INCAPABLE OF BEING MECHANICALLY OR ANALYTICALLY SEPARATED OR DETERMINED.  (P. 2523-1)

TO CLOSE THE SENATE DOORS IN THE IMPEACHMENT TRIAL OF U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE ALBERT SWAYNE OF THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA, WHILE DECIDING UPON THE ADMISSIBILITY OF EVIDENCE OFFERED BY MR. DE ARMOND, ONE OF THE HOUSE MANAGERS, CONSISTING OF CERTAIN VOLUNTARY STATEMENTS MADE BY SWAYNE BEFORE THE HOUSE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE HEARING UPON HIS RESIDENCE IN NORTHERN FLORIDA AND UPON CERTAIN CONTEMPT PROCEEDINGS IN WHICH HE DELIBERATED AS U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE IN NORTHERN FLORIDA.

TO DECIDE THE ADMISSIBILITY OF EVIDENCE IN THE IMPEACHMENT TRIAL OF CHARLES SWAYNE, U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE IN AND FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA; WHICH EVIDENCE, CONSTITUTES VOLUNTARY STATEMENTS MADE BY SWAYNE BEFORE THE HOUSE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE CONCERNING HIS RESIDENCE IN THE JUDICIAL DISTRICT TO WHICH HE HAD BEEN APPOINTED JUDGE AND CONCERNING CERTAIN CONTEMPT PROCEEDINGS IN WHICH HE DILIBERATED AS U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE IN NORTHERN FLORIDA.

TO AMEND H.R. 16986, A BILL REGARDING CONSTRUCTION OF THE PANAMA CANAL AND TO PROVIDE FOR THE GOVERNMENT OF THE CANAL ZONE BY LIMITING THE USE OF VESSELS FOR THE CONSTRUCTION AND OPERATION OF THE CANAL AND ITS RAILROAD, TO U.S. SHIPS ONLY; NO QUORUM VOTING.

TO DECIDE THE ADMISSIBILITY OF EVIDENCE IN THE IMPEACHMENT TRIAL OF CHARLES SWAYNE, JUDGE OF THE U.S. DISTRICT COURT IN AND FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA; WHICH EVIDENCE, OBJECTED TO BY THE HOUSE MANAGERS, IS OFFERED BY DEFENSE COUNSEL IN THE FORM OF EXTRACTS FROM THE CONGRESSIONAL RECORD DELINEATING, AS PART OF THE PARLIAMENTARY HISTORY OF THE ENACTMENT OF LAWS, THE LEGAL CONSTRUCTION TAKEN IN THE MATTER OF COMPENSATION ALLOWED TO U.S. CIRCUIT AND DISTRICT COURT JUDGES.

TO DECIDE THE ADMISSIBILITY OF EVIDENCE IN THE IMPEACHMENT TRIAL OF CHARLES SWAYNE, U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE IN AND FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA, WHICH EVIDENCE, OFFERED BY DEFENSE COUNSEL AND ATTESTED BY THE SECRETARY OF TREASURY AS A TRUE STATEMENT FROM TREASURY BOOKS, BUT NOT UNDER SEAL, PURPORTS TO SHOW EXPENSE CLAIMS OF U.S. CIRCUIT COURT JUDGES ALLOWED WHILE ATTENDING COURTS AWAY FROM THEIR RESIDENCES OR OUT OF THEIR OWN DISTRICTS.

TO DECIDE THE GUILT OR INNOCENCE OF CHARLES SWAYNE, U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE IN AND FOR THE NORTHER DISTRICT OF FLORIDA, OF THE CHARGES IN THE FIRST ARTICLE OF IMPEACHMENT AGAINST HIM WHICH DECLARES THAT SWAYNE ON 4/20/1897, PRE- SENTED TO U.S. MARSHAL R.M. LOVE IN WACO, TEXAS, A FALSE CLAIM OF $230 AGAINST THE U.S. WHILE U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE FOR NORTHERN FLA., ALSO KNOWINGLY MADE AND USED A FALSE CERTIFICATE FACILITATING PAYMENT OF HIS CLAIM.

TO DECIDE THE GUILT OR INNOCENCE OF CHARLES SWAYNE, U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE IN AND FOR THE NORTHERN DIST. OF FLA. TO THE SECOND ARTICLE OF IMPEACHMENT WHICH DECLARES THAT HE FALSELY CERTIFIED THAT HIS REASONABLE EXPENSES FOR TRAVEL AND ATTENDENCE AMOUNTED TO THE MAXIMUM ALLOWED, $10 PER DAY FOR 24 DAYS WHILE HOLDING COURT AT TYLER, TEXAS, BEGINNING DEC. 3, 1900, AND FOR 7 DAYS ENROUTE TO AND FROM FLORIDA, AND UPON HIS CERTIFICATE, TO THE U.S. MARSHAL IN WHICH THE COURT WAS HELD, HE RECEIVED $310, WHEREAS HIS EXPENSES WERE LESS THAN $10 PER DAY, AND THAT, THEREFORE, HE MISBEHAVED AND IS GUILTY OF THE HIGH CRIME OF OBTAINING MONEY FROM THE U.S. UNDER FALSE PRETENSE, COMMITTING A HIGH MISDEMEANOR IN OFFICE.

TO DECIDE THE GUILT OR INNOCENCE OF CHARLES SWAYNE, U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE IN AND FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF FLA., OF THE CHARGES IN THE 3RD ARTICLE OF IMPEACHMENT AGAINST HIM WHICH DECLARES THAT AS A U.S. JUDGE HE FALSELY CERTIFIED HIS REASONABLE TRAVEL EXPENSES TO AND FROM TYLER, TEXAS, WERE $310, WHICH HE RECEIVED FROM A U.S. MARSHAL, WHEN HIS EXPENSES ACTUALLY WERE MUCH LESS, WHEREFORE HE IS GUILTY OF A HIGH MISDEMEANOR IN OFFICE CONSTITUTED BY HAVING OBTAINED MONEY FROM THE U.S. BY FALSE PRETENSE.

TO DECIDE THE QUILT OR INNOCENCE OF CHARLES SWAYNE, U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE IN AND FOR THE NORTHERN DIST. OF FLA., OF THE CHARGES IN THE 4TH ARTICLE OF IMPEACHMENT AGAINST HIM WHICH DECLARES THAT HE, AS A U.S. JUDGE IN 1893, UNLAWFULLY APPROPRIATED TO HIS OWN USE A RAILROAD CAR OF THE JACKSONVILLE, TAMPA AND KEY WEST RAILROAD COMPANY FOR TRANSPORTING HIMSELF, FAMILY AND FRIENDS FROM GUYENCOURT, DEL. TO JACKSONVILLE, FLA., WHEN THE RAILROAD WAS IN THE HANDS OF A RECEIVER, UNDER A CLAIM OF RIGHT BECAUSE HE APPOINTED THE COMPANY'S RECEIVER, WHEREFORE HE IS GUILTY OF ABUSE OF JUDICIAL POWER AND OF A HIGH DEMEANOR IN OFFICE.

TO DECIDE THE GUILD OR INNOCENCE OF CHARLES SWAYNE, U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE IN AND FOR THE NORTHEN DISTRICT OF FLA., OF THE CHARGES IN THE FIFTH ARTICLE OF IMPEACHMENT AGAINST HIM WHICH ACCUSES HIM, AS A U.S. JUDGE IN 1893, OF UNLAWFULLY APPROPRIATING FOR USE OF HIMSELF, FAMILY AND FRIENDS, A RAILROAD CAR OF THE JACKSONVILLE, TAMPA AND KEY WEST RAILROAD COMPANY, UNDER A CLAIM OF RIGHT BECAUSE HE HAD APPOINTED THE COMPANY'S RECEIVER, WHEREFORE HE IS GUILTY OF ABUSE OF JUDICIAL POWER AND OF HIGH MIS- DEMEANOR IN OFFICE.

TO DECIDE THE GUILT OR INNOCENCE OF CHARLES SWAYNE, U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE IN AND FOR THE NORTHERN DIST. OF FLA. OF THE CHARGES IN THE 6TH ARTICLE OF IMPEACHMENT AGAINST HIM DECLARING THAT HE, AS U.S. JUDGE FROM THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA, ESTABLISHED HIS HOME IN ST. AUGUSTINE ON APRIL 22, 1890, BUT FAILED TO MOVE WHEN ON JULY 23, 1894 ST. AUGUSTINE WAS PLACED IN THE SOUTHERN DISTRICT, AND THAT HE LIVED, IN VIOLATION OF LAW, OUTSIDE THE DISTRICT HE SERVED AS JUDGE, FOR SIX YEARS, WHEREFORE HE WAS AND IS GUILTY OF A HIGH MISDEMEANOR IN OFFICE.

TO DECIDE THE GUILT OR INNOCENCE OF CHARLES SWAYNE, U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE IN AND FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA, OF THE CHARGES IN THE 7TH ARTICLE OF IMPEACHMENT AGAINST HIM DECLARING THAT AS A U.S. JUDGE FOR NORTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA AND KNOWING THE LAW REQUIRED HIM TO LIVE IN THAT DISTRICT, HE LIVED FROM JULY 23, 1894 TO JAN. 1, 1903 OTHER THAN IN THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA, THUS WILLFULLY AND KNOWINGLY VIOLATING THE LAW, WHEREFORE HE IS AND WAS GUILTY OF A HIGH MISDEMEANOR IN OFFICE.

TO DECIDE THE GUILT OR INNOCENCE OF CHARLES SWAYNE, U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE IN AND FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA, OF THE CHARGE IN THE 8TH ARTICLE OF IMPEACHMENT AGAINST HIM DECLARING THAT ON NOVEMBER 12, 1901, HE MALICIOUSLY AND UNLAWFULLY ADJUDGED E.T. DAVIS, A LAWYER, GUILTY OF CONTEMPT OF COURT, FINING HIM $100 AND COMMITTING HIM TO JAIL FOR TEN DAYS, WHEREFORE HE IS GUILTY OF A HIGH MISDEMEANOR IN OFFICE.

TO DECIDE THE GUILT OR INNOCENCE OF CHARLES SWAYNE, U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE IN AND FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA, OF THE CHARGE IN THE 9TH ARTICLE OF IMPEACHMENT AGAINST HIM DECLARING THAT ON NOV. 12, 1901, HE KNOWINGLY AND UNLAWFULLY ADJUDGED E.T. DAVIS, A LAWYER, GUILTY OF CONTEMPT OF COURT, FINING HIM $100 AND COMMITTING HIM TO JAIL FOR TEN DAYS, WHEREFORE HE MISBEHAVED AS JUDGE AND WAS AND IS GUILTY OF ABUSE OF JUDICIAL POWER AND OF A HIGH MISDEMEANOR IN OFFICE.

TO DECIDE THE GUILT OR INNOCENCE OF CHARLES SWAYNE, U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE IN AND FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA, OF CHARGE IN THE TENTH ARTICLE OF IMPEACHMENT AGAINST HIM DECLARING THAT ON NOV. 12, 1901, HE MALICIOUSLY AND UNLAWFULLY ADJUDGED SIMEON BELDEN, A LAWYER, GUILTY OF CONTEMPT OF THE U.S. CIRCUIT COURT, FINING HIM $100 AND JAILING HIM FOR TEN DAYS, WHEREFORE HE MISBEHAVED AS JUDGE AND IS AND WAS GUILTY OF ABUSE OF JUDICIAL POWER AND OF A HIGH MISDEMEANOR IN OFFICE.

TO DECIDE THE GUILT OR INNOCENCE OF CHARLES SWAYNE, U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE IN AND FOR THE NORTHER DISTRICT OF FLA., OF THE CHARGES IN THE 11TH ARTICLE OF IMPEACHMENT AGAINST HIM DECLARING THAT WHILE HE WAS A U.S. JUDGE ON NOVEMBER 12, 1901, HE KNOWINGLY AND UNLAWFULLY ADJUDGED SIMEON BELDEN, A LAWYER, GUILTY OF CONTEMPT OF THE U.S. CIRCUIT COURT, FINING HIM $100 AND JAILING HIM FOR TEN DAYS, WHEREFORE HE MISBEHAVED AS JUDGE AND WAS AND IS GUILTY OF ABUSE OF THE JUDICIAL POWER AND OF A HIGH MISDEMEANOR IN OFFICE.

TO DECIDE THE GUILT OR INNOCENCE OF CHARLES SWAYNE, U.S. DISTRICT COURT JUDGE IN AND FOR THE NORTHERN DIST. OF FLA., FLORIDA, TO CHARGE IN THE TWELFTH ARTICLE OF IMPEACHMENT AGAINST HIM DECLARING THAT ON DEC. 9, 1902, WHILE A U.S. JUDGE, HE UNLAWFULLY AND KNOWINGLY COMMITTED W.C. O'NEAL TO JAIL FOR 60 DAYS FOR CONTEMPT OF THE U.S. DISTRICT COURT FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA, WHEREFORE HE MISBEHAVED AS JUDGE AND WAS AND IS GUILTY OF ABUSE OF THE JUDICIAL POWER AND OF A HIGH MISDEMEANOR IN OFFICE.

TO AMEND H.R. 18467, (APP. 3-3-05, 33 STAT. L. 1092), A BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR NAVAL SERVICE FOR THE FISCAL YEAR ENDING JUNE 30, 1906 AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES, REDUCING THE NUMBER OF BATTLESHIPS TO BE BUILT FROM TWO TO ONE; MOTION REJECTED.

TO DECIDE THE POINT OF ORDER THAT THE AMENDMENT PROPOSING THAT NO PORTION OF THE FUNDS APPROPRIATED BY THIS ACT OR THE PRINCIPAL OR INTEREST OF ANY INDIAN TRUST OR TRIBAL FUND HELD BY THE U.S. FOR THE BENEFIT OF ANY INDIAN TRIBE SHALL USED FOR THE SUPPORT OF ANY SECTARIAN OR DENOMINATIONAL SCHOOL, PROVIDED THAT ANY BENEFICIARY OF ANY INTEREST IN SUCH FUNDS, DESIRING TO EDUCATE HIS CHILD OR WARD IN ANY OTHER SCHOOL, OTHER THAN GOVERNMENT, MAY BE A WRITTIN ORDER SIGNED BY HIM, DIRECT THE INTEREST ACCURING TO HIM, TO BE PAID TO THE SCHOOL IN WHICH SUCH CHILD MAY BE EDUCATED-, IS NOT RELEVANT OR GERMANE TO THE SUBJECT MATTER OF H.R. 17474, (APP. 3-3-05, 33 STAT. L. 1048), APPROPRIATING FOR THE CURRENT AND CONTINGENT EXPENSES OF THE INDIAN DEPARTMENT AND FOR FULFILLING TREATY STIPULATIONS WITH INDIAN TRIBES FOR YEAR EIDING JUNE 30, 1906.
TO AMEND H.R. 17474, BY GIVING THE INDIAN THE RIGHT TO DECIDE WHETHER ANY PART OF HIS SHARE OF THE TRIBAL INTEREST FUND COULD BE USED FOR THE EDUCATION OF HIS CHILD, CHILDREN OR WARD.  (P. 3622-1)

TO SUSTAIN THE DECISION OF THE CHAIR DURING CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 17474, WHICH DECISION RULED AS NOT BEING IN ORDER, AN AMENDMENT PROPOSING THAT CLAIMANTS TO CITIZENSHIP IN THE FIVE CIVILIZED TRIBES WHO ARE OF INDIAN BLOOD, WHOSE NAME ARE ON TRIBAL ROLLS AS CITIZENS AND WHOSE CLAIMS HAVE BEEN REJECTED OR MAY BE BY THE COMMISSIONER TO THE FINE CIVILIZED TRIBES, SHALL HAVE RIGHT FOR NINETY DAYS FROM THE APPROVAL OF THIS ACT, OR FOR NINETY FROM THE APPROVAL OF SUCH REJECTION BY THE SECRETARY OF THE INTERIOR, TO SELL THEIR IMPROVEMENTS UPON THE LANDS WHICH THEY HAVE OCCUPIED AS THEIR HOMES OR HELD FOR ALLOTMENTS FOR THEIR MINOR CHILDREN, TO OTHER CITIZENS OF SUCH TRIBE HAVING LAWFUL RIGHT TO ACQUIRE THE SAME, BUT IN N  CASE SHALL THIS PRIVILEGE EXTEND TO AN AREA OF MORE THAN STANDARD ALLOTMENT FOR EACH PERSON.  (P. 3683-2)

TO AGREE TO THE FIRST DIVISION OF AMENDMENT TO H.R. 17865, (APP. 3-3-05, 33 STAT. L. 1082), A BILL MAKING APPROPRIAT- IONS FOR THE SERVICE OF THE POST OFFICE DEPARTMENT FOR YEAR ENDING JUNE 30, 1906, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES, WHICH AMENDMENT INCREASES THE APPROPRIATION FOR THE TRANSMISSION OF MAIL BY PNEUMATIC TUBES AND OTHER SIMILAR DEVICES FROM $500,000.00 TO $800,000.  (P. 3731-2,3732-2)

TO AMEND THE FIRST DIVISION OF THE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 17865, (APP. 3-3-05, 33 STAT. L. 1082), A BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE SERVICE OS THE POST OFFICE DEPARTMENT FOR YEAR ENDING JUNE 30, 1906, AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES WHICH AMENDMENT RAISING THE APPROPRIATION FOR PNEUMATIC MAIL TUBES AND OTHER SIMILAR DEVICES FROM $500,000 TO $800,000 AND AUTHORIZING THE POSTMASTER GENERAL TO EXTEND THE SERVICE UNDER THE ACT OF APRIL 21, 1902.
TO PASS S.J.RES. 114, PROPOSING TO CONTINUE IN FORCE THE PROVISIONS OF SECTION 2 OF AN ACT TO PROVIDE FOR THE TEMPORARY GOVERNMENT OF THE CANAL ZONE AT PANAMA, APRIL 28, 1904.
TO PROCEED TO CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 12273 (APP. 3-3-05, 33, STAT. L. 1263), A BILL AUTHORIZING THE APPOINTMENT OF CERTAIN MIDSHIPMEN IN THE U.S. NAVY.
